headline: Double-Chocolate Bundt Cake with Ganache Glaze
description: Many Bundt cakes are heavy and buttery, but this one is surprisingly light and incredibly moist under its silky chocolate glaze. Strong-brewed coffee ...
name: Double-Chocolate Bundt Cake with Ganache Glaze

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350Â°. Spray a 12-cup Bundt pan with vegetable oil spray. In a small saucepan, melt 2 ounces of the chopped chocolate over low heat, stirring constantly. Scrape the chocolate into a medium bowl and let cool slightly. Whisk in the oil and sugar until smooth, then whisk in the egg.

In a small bowl, whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda and salt. Add half of the dry ingredients to the chocolate mixture along with 1/2 cup of the coffee and 1/2 cup of the buttermilk; whisk until smooth. Add the remaining dry ingredients, coffee and buttermilk and whisk until smooth.

Pour the batter into the prepared pan and bake in the lower third of the oven for about 45 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center of the cake comes out with a few moist crumbs attached. Let the cake cool on a rack for 10 minutes, then turn it out and let cool completely.

In a small saucepan, bring the cream to a boil. In a heatproof bowl, combine the remaining 3 ounces of chopped chocolate with the corn syrup and butter. Pour the hot cream over the chocolate and let stand until melted, about 5 minutes. Whisk until smooth. Let the ganache glaze cool until thick but still pourable, about 5 minutes.
Pour the ganache over the cooled cake.Let the cake stand until the glaze is set, at least 30 minutes, before serving.

review.reviewBody: Looks beautiful, can't wait to try it. Thank you. One suggestion, I've made the mistake (totally because I failed to read the full recipe first!) before of adding the full amount of something because it is listed only once in the recipe even though it is divided for the cake and frosting (as in the chopped chocolate). I like a recipe that divides the ingredients as they should be used in the cake and the frosting separately and labelled as such.

I actually use this recipe for regular, layered cakes. I leave it in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours prior to use. It becomes a bit more dense and just heavenly- it's the best recipe I've ever used and it gets raving reviews from everyone!
Honestly the best chocolate cake that I've ever had. Beautifully rich chocolate flavor while remaining light and moist. Recipe was very easy to follow.
